contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person |name = Lionel George Curtis |image = |image_size = |caption = | birth_date = 1872 | birth_place = | death_date = 1955 |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] |known_for = Leading [[Milner's Kindergarten]] |education = |alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]] |occupation = [[Professor]] |home_town = |title = |term = |religion = |spouse = |children = |relatives = |signature = |website = }} '''Lionel George Curtis''' (1872–1955) was a British official and author. He advocated [[Imperial Federation|British Empire Federalism]]<ref>{{cite book |author=Fromkin, David |title=A Peace to end all Peace |year=1989|page=232}}</ref> and, late in life, a [[world state]]. His ideas concerning [[dyarchy]] were important in the development of the [[Government of India Act 1919]] and more generally, his writings influenced the evolution of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. ==Life== Curtis was born at [[Coddington, Herefordshire]] in 1872, the youngest of the four children of an [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] [[rector (ecclesiastical)#Anglican churches|rector]].<ref>Tom Cargill: How to build a better world. ''History Today'', Vol. 63, No. 2 (February 2013).</ref> He was educated at [[Haileybury College]] and then at [[New College, Oxford]], where he read law. He fought in the [[Second Boer War]] with the [[City Imperial Volunteers]] and served as secretary to [[Lord Milner]] (a position that had also been held by adventure-novelist [[John Buchan]]), during which time he dedicated himself to working for a united self-governing South Africa. Following Milner's death in 1925, he became the second leader of [[Milner's Kindergarten]] until his own death in 1955. His experience led him to conceptualize his version of a [[Federal World Government]], which became his life work. In pursuit of this goal, he founded (1910) the quarterly ''[[The Round Table Journal|Round Table]]''. He was appointed (1912) Beit lecturer in colonial history at the [[University of Oxford]], and a Fellow of [[All Souls College, Oxford|All Souls College]]. In 1919 Curtis led a delegation of British and American experts to organize the [[Royal Institute of International Affairs]] during the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Peace Conference of Paris]].<ref>Edgar Trevor Williams, A. F. Madden, David Kenneth Fieldhouse. Oxford and the Idea of Commonwealth. Routledge, 1982. (Pages 39, 98)</ref> ==Works== Curtis' most important books were: * ''The Commonwealth of Nations'' (1916); * ''Dyarchy'' (1920); and, * ''Civitas Dei: The Commonwealth of God'' (1938), arguing that the [[United States]] must rejoin the [[Commonwealth of Nations|British commonwealth]] and that the Commonwealth must evolve into a [[world government]]. ==References== * ''World Revolution In The Cause of Peace'', Basil Blackwell, Oxford (1949) * ''From Empire to International Commonwealth: A Biography of Lionel Curtis'' by Deborah Lavin, Oxford University Press (1995), ISBN 0-19-812616-6 * ''The Round Table movement and imperial union'' by John Edward Kendle, University of Toronto Press (1975), ISBN 0-8020-5292-4 * ''The Anglo-American Establishment by Professor Carroll Quigley <references/> ==External links== *[http://www.houseofdavid.ca/rou_tab.pdf Round Table Movement - Past and Future, 1913] *[http://www.houseofdavid.ca/dyarch.htm Papers relating to the application of the principle of DYARCHY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF- INDIA, 1920] *{{NRA|P7225}} {{Authority control|VIAF=17312732}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Curtis, Lionel George | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1872 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1955 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Curtis, Lionel George}} [[Category:1872 births]] [[Category:1955 deaths]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Second Boer War]] [[Category:British journalists]] [[Category:Editors of the Round Table Journal]] [[Category:Administrators in British India]] [[Category:People educated at Haileybury and Imperial Service College]] [[Category:Fellows of All Souls College, Oxford]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:City Imperial Volunteers officers]]
